sub_title: Physicist & Data Scientist | Creating insight by developing data-driven predictive models | Scientist at TNO
summary:
I am an experienced researcher, skilled at computer programming (12 years of experience), with a strong technical background (PhD in statistical physics) and a deep passion for discovering hidden patterns and trends in the data.

Me at a glance:
- More than five years of experience in data analysis and modelling in the field of biological physics.
- PhD in statistical physics. Solid knowledge of mathematics and statistics 
- Fluent in various programming languages (Python, R, MATLAB, C++). 
- Hands-on experience with Machine-Learning techniques.
- Experience with leading and working in multidisciplinary research teams.

My professional aspirations:
I am enthusiastic to explore different kinds of data, tackle new challenges, and find solutions for the problems that I might have not encountered before. I greatly enjoy working in research teams, and I am interested in challenging jobs which, ideally, combine industrial research with data analysis, so I can apply my expertise to the fullest.

My expertise:
My expertise is in predictive (i.e. statistical) modelling, with a focus on stochastic (i.e. random) processes. The techniques I am working with have a vast range of application, from predicting earthquakes to modelling the stock market. In my career as a researcher I have focused on elucidating (noisy) biological processes at the molecular level. I have exploited advanced statistical techniques, such as Bayesian inference and machine learning, to develop statistical models with the goal of making sense of and predicting complex biological data. Through this I have developed a great passion for discovering hidden patterns and trends in the data in general.

Contact me:
If you have an interesting data science project in mind, or simply would like to have a scientific chat, feel free to message me on LinkedIn or send an email to behrooz.eslami@gmail.com
I would always welcome a new mental challenge!

projects.title: Predicting the occurrence and impact of droughts from meteorological time-series
projects.description:
I am involved in this project as a professional volunteer for the Dutch Red Cross. I am part of the 510 team, whose mission is to use data driven modeling to make humanitarian aid more efficient. The Impact-Based-Forecasting (IBF) project aims to predict the occurrence and the impact of natural disasters such as floods and droughts, thereby converting data to actionable insights. Through this, the communities can be warned and the necessary actions can be taken in advanced.

I am currently working on a newly formed branch of the IBF project, building a predictive model for the occurrence and impact of droughts in Uganda and Kenya. This project is still in a preliminary phase. I will regularly update the following repository as I progress:  

https://github.com/behroozeslami/Impact_Based_Forecasting_Droughts

projects.title: Designing an optimal classifier to estimate (and reduce) the risk of gene therapy applications
projects.description:
As a senior researcher/data modelling expert in the Depken lab (Bio-nanoscience department, TU Delft) I am the lead researcher in the CRISPR project. CRISPR systems are highly popular tools for gene editing. Nevertheless, their clinical applications are limited by the fact that they sometimes make mistakes and target a wrong place in the DNA, and this might have grave consequences. 

Working with an amazing group of students at TU Delft, I am trying to build an optimal classifier to identify the errors made in CRISPR-based gene-editing procedures. The classifier is based on a stochastic predictive model (Markov chain), trained on real data using a multidimensional nonlinear regression implemented as a costume-written Python code (scripts can be accessed here: https://github.com/KleinMisha/Energy_Landscape_dCas9). Our predictive model, and the resultant classifier, outperforms the other existing predictive tools.

This project is of curtail importance for the assessment (and minimizing) the risk in medical treatments which involve CRISPR systems.

contributors.headline: Physicist & Data Scientist | Creating insight by developing data-driven predictive models | Scientist at TNO
Postdoctoral Scientist, Biophysics of SARS-CoV2 replication  bij Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam

projects.title: Extracting information out of extremely noisy time-series
projects.description:
In a collaboration with Prof. N.H. Dekker lab (TU Delft) I am the principal data analysist, responsible to build a predictive model based on (biological) noisy time series. As the time-series have extremely low signal-to-noise ratio (smaller than 5%), it is challenging to separate the actual trend in the data from the noise. To overcome this challenge I developed a new approach (based on the dwell-time analysis technique) which incorporate the noise into the model. This approach can be viewed as an alternative to the hidden Markov models.

Based on this novel approach, I have developed a complete data analysis pipeline to process and model a large collection (few hundred) of time-series and extract their determining features over a large timescale (from 1/10th of a second to  couple of hours). 

Through this analysis, I have proposed a statistical model to describe the dynamic behavior of these time-series (see my recently published papers for more details: 

https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/762468v1 and https://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(18)30852-3. The costume-written MATLAB scripts can be found here: https://github.com/behroozeslami/RNAP_Dynamics

projects.title: Discovering a hidden layer of information on DNA
projects.description:
As a researcher at Leiden University, I developed a new computational method, called Mutation Monte Carlo, which allowed for an efficient search through a vast space of sequences (~10^88 sequences). Using this method, I was able to identify patterns in the DNA sequence which dictates its flexibility. This led to the discovery of a second layer of information on DNA (see 
https://www.universiteitleiden.nl/en/news/2016/06/second-layer-of-information-in-dna-confirmed). 

The C++ code to implement the Mutation Monte Carlo can be found here:

https://github.com/behroozeslami/Motation_Monte_Calo/blob/master/Seq_MC_nucleosome_14bs.cpp

profile_positions.description: The building and construction industry is full of innovative ideas. TNO helps companies (building and construction companies, suppliers, architects) to make this tangible by sharing knowledge and providing advice. At the same time, we are committed to making the built environment more sustainable by creating comfortable, healthy and energy-neutral buildings for both new and existing buildings.
profile_positions.title: Scientist | Building Physics & Systems

profile_positions.title: Data Scientist

profile_positions.description:
Project CRISPR

•	Lead in CRISPR (gene editing) project in the Depken lab, assessing and minimizing the risk in medical treatments. 
•	Created an optimal classifier to identify the errors in gene-editing procedures, based on a stochastic predictive model (Markov chain). Our predictive model, and the resultant classifier, outperforms the other existing predictive tools.

Project RNAP

•	Principal data analyst in collaboration with Prof. N.H. Dekker lab in building a predictive model based on (biological) noisy time series. 
•	Developed a new approach (based on the dwell-time analysis technique), which incorporates the noise into the model, as an alternative to the hidden Markov models. 
•	Designed complete data analysis pipeline to process and model a large collection (few hundred) of time-series and extract their determining features over a large timescale (from 1/10th of a second to couple of hours).
profile_positions.title: Senior Researcher / Data Modelling Expert

profile_positions.description:
•	Developed a new computational method to discover hidden patterns in human DNA.
•	Implemented the algorithm as a C++ tool (~3000 lines of code) to be able to search through enormous volumes of DNA sequences within a couple of minutes, to choose those that show a specific pattern.  
•	Discovered a second layer of information on DNA.
